awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Developing NLP-based Platform Technology for Phage-Host Interaction Predictions
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve agricultural operations with respect to infection.  Antibiotic resistance in crops is increasing. One of the most promising alternatives to antibiotics is bacteriophages, also known as phages. Phages are safe bacterial viruses already used on a small commercial scale in the United States. One major bottleneck for phage use in a larger number of diseases is the difficulty involved in selecting phages that will be effective against the target pathogen. This project addresses this challenge by aiming to develop a state-of-the-art computational approach to select phages against a range of diseases in a rapid and efficient manner. This technology will allow for widespread phage use as a safer and more efficient substitution for antibiotics. Additionally, the final deliverable of this project includes developing the first-ever phage-based, sustainable, and cost-effective antimicrobial solution against Huanglongbing, a devastating and completely incurable bacterial disease of citruses.

The proposed project aims to remove a key bottleneck in the bacteriophage field by building the first-ever commercially viable platform technology to computationally predict phage-host interactions. Specifically, it is currently difficult and time-consuming to select bacteriophages against target pathogens as this manual process is inefficient.  Moreover, phages cannot be isolated against uncultivable bacteria. The proposed project aims to use cutting-edge Natural Language Processing for bacteriophage use against an increasing number of pathogens. This proposal’s first objective is to significantly improve the already built models and show that their predictions hold in vitro using the gold-standard plaque assay experiments. This proposal’s second objective is to use this platform technology and wet-lab methods to produce and test the first-ever antibacterial (phage-based) solution that works against the currently incurable Huanglongbing disease caused by an uncultivable pathogen. This project will further help determine if Transformer-based models can excel at complex genome understanding tasks and produce in-vitro-viable viral-host interaction predictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project explored the potential of using transformer-based models to better understand how viruses interact with their hosts, focusing on two main types: bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria) and influenza viruses. Our goal was to harness cutting-edge approaches from data science to predict these interactions, improving how we respond to and manage infectious diseases. 

Bacteriophage-Bacteria Model

Our project aimed to develop a machine learning model, using advanced Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, to predict interactions between bacteriophages and their bacterial hosts. This was in response to the growing global issue of antibiotic resistance and the need for new treatments. By treating genomic material as a language, we utilized a transformer-based model and positive unlabeled (PU) learning to innovate beyond traditional methods dependent on manual phage isolation, which are ineffective with uncultivable bacteria. This approach represents a significant shift in how we predict and potentially control bacterial infections.

Our project successfully developed a transformer-based model that predicted bacteriophage-host interactions with a 70% accuracy rate with a focus on E. coli strains. This model was able to identify hidden associations in the data, even when similar pairs were not dominant in the training set. This marks the first successful application of transformer technology in predicting virus interactions across multiple strains of a bacterial species, demonstrating the potential of such models in the field of viral-host interactions given adequate data.

Influenza-Human Model 

The ability to accurately predict the threat posed by emerging viruses to human health is a vital component of public health and safety. Accurate predictions can inform timely responses, guide vaccine development, and shape preventive measures, ultimately saving lives and mitigating widespread impacts. This proactive approach is essential in a world where emerging viruses pose an ever-evolving threat to global health security. 

As the first step to achieving this ambitious goal, we focused on developing an advanced large-language model-like natural language processing (LLM-like NLP) model to predict which viruses can infect humans using information from whole genome sequencing.  It achieved an accuracy of 99.4% and an AUC ROC of 99.24 when tested on a balanced dataset. This performance is unmatched and stands out as a significant accomplishment in the published research. Such a model, especially if it were to become universal for all eukaryotic viruses, could become the key component in identifying new emerging threats, including bioterrorism ones, and identifying which viruses were likely human-made. Moreover, generative modeling could further allow the use of viruses for very-targeted, beneficial purposes.

Overall, this work showed that using LLMs for virus-host interaction predictions in prokaryotes and eukaryotes is a very promising direction, and established the most successful example so far of such a model. Importantly, similar approaches were successfully used for both prokaryotic and eukaryotic viruses as well as DNA and RNA-based viruses, showing the general applicability across different “genomic languages” and species. The model showed remarkable predictive abilities (99.4% accurate at predicting if influenza strains could infect humans). This means that this model can be further used for more general viral-host interaction tasks and pathogenicity of specific strains. The procedures of data collection, model training, and predictions were completed correctly and established a framework for future genomic work on viral-host interactions. The largest dataset with complete influenza genomes was assembled.

Modified by: Sofia Sigal-Passeck
